dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A free train ticket for a kid under seven? That seems way too generous, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A free train ticket for a kid under seven? That seems way too generous, honestly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's actually a pretty common policy, and Kazakhstan's national railway is just reminding parents before the summer rush. One child per adult can ride free, but only if they don't take up a separate seat.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's actually a pretty common policy, and Kazakhstan's national railway is just reminding parents before the summer rush. One child per adult can ride free, but only if they don't take up a separate seat.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to JSC Passenger Transportation, one child under the age of 7 (that is, until they turn 7) can travel for free without a separate seat. If a family is traveling with multiple children under 7, only one child per adult can travel for free.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But what if you've got, like, two little ones? That's gotta get expensive fast.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But what if you've got, like, two little ones? That's gotta get expensive fast.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, so for multiple kids under seven, only one travels free per adult. The others need a child ticket, which is half-price for ages seven to fifteen.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, so for multiple kids under seven, only one travels free per adult. The others need a child ticket, which is half-price for ages seven to fifteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If a family is traveling with multiple children under 7, only one child per adult can travel for free. Children between the ages of 7 and 15 are eligible to travel with a child ticket, which costs 50 percent of the full adult fare.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Half-price until fifteen? That's not bad at all. But what about older teens traveling alone?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Half-price until fifteen? That's not bad at all. But what about older teens traveling alone?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: From age fifteen, they need a full adult ticket, and if they're traveling solo, they have to carry a notarized letter of consent from their guardian.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: From age fifteen, they need a full adult ticket, and if they're traveling solo, they have to carry a notarized letter of consent from their guardian.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From the age of 15, a full adult ticket must be purchased. Teenagers aged 15 and over may travel alone but must carry a notarized letter of consent from their legal guardian, the company added.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, a notarized letter? That sounds like a hassle for families.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, a notarized letter? That sounds like a hassle for families.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's for safety, you know? And it's the same if someone who isn't the legal guardian is taking the child—both parents have to provide that permission letter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's for safety, you know? And it's the same if someone who isn't the legal guardian is taking the child-both parents have to provide that permission letter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If a child is accompanied by someone who is not their legal guardian, a notarized letter of permission from both parents is required, the statement said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but what about international travel? I bet the rules are totally different.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but what about international travel? I bet the rules are totally different.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They are! For trips outside Kazakhstan, kids under five ride free without a seat, five to ten get a child fare, and ten to fifteen pay half within Kazakhstan but full fare abroad.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They are! For trips outside Kazakhstan, kids under five ride free without a seat, five to ten get a child fare, and ten to fifteen pay half within Kazakhstan but full fare abroad.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Children under 5 can travel for free without a separate seat. Children aged 10 to 15 pay 50 percent of the full fare within Kazakhstan, but the full fare when traveling in other countries, the company said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So it really pays to double-check based on the route.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So it really pays to double-check based on the route.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And they always need to show a birth certificate or passport when boarding, just to keep everything smooth and secure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And they always need to show a birth certificate or passport when boarding, just to keep everything smooth and secure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company also reminded passengers that when traveling with a parent, a child's birth certificate or passport must be shown when purchasing tickets and boarding the train.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Makes sense. I guess it's all about balancing convenience with safety, especially with extra summer trains running.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes sense. I guess it's all about balancing convenience with safety, especially with extra summer trains running.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Summer routes: additional trains will be launched in Kazakhstan

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Keeping an eye on the little ones is a big part of it too—always supervised, always documented.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Keeping an eye on the little ones is a big part of it too-always supervised, always documented.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The national rail operator also strongly advises following safety rules and ensuring children are always supervised by adults.
